metadata.title: Genes for two homologous G-protein a subunits map to different human chromosomes

abstract.original_text: Signal transduction across biological membranes is modulated by a family of related GTP-binding proteins termed G proteins. These G proteins have a heterotrimeric structure composed of (i, [~, and 7 subunits. The (i subunits of the G proteins bind GTP and appear to determine the biochemical specificity of the protein. We have recently cloned and characterized cDNA encoding two G-protein (i subunits, (i i and %. The former is a substrate for ADP-ribosylation by pertussis toxin. The protein corresponding to (ih has not yet been identified. These cDNAs encode proteins, which demonstrate 90% sequence identity to one another and also show marked similarity to other G proteins. The present studies were designed to determine whether the genes for these related proteins are clustered on a single human chromosome. Genomic DNA isolated from a panel of mouse-human hybrid cell lines was analyzed by hybridization to cDNAs for (1 i and %. Based on the distribution patterns of (ii and % in cell hybrids, the gene for cq was assigned to human chromosome 7, and the gene for % assigned to chromosome 12. These data suggest that the G-protein gene family may be distributed over at least two human chromosomes.
